Reviews.Title: MURS Alert Transmitter
Reviews.Author: TimberrockRanch
Reviews.Content: Previously I had purchased an MURS transmitter and receiver kit from a different source and have just now purchased an additional transmitter through Amazon. I may have been less inclined to purchase a Dakota device based on some of the poor performance reviews, especially ingress of water. But, my own experience has been fine so far. After reading a couple of reviews I decided to look into the case of the first transmitter and inspect for water. We have had nearly 5" of rain in the last few weeks, the unit is exposed on a tree, and there was no water inside. I believe my success is attributed to the one thing I did before I mounted it. Right from the start, I did not like the telescoping antenna, so I replaced it with a cut piece of coax (shield removed for the same length as the extended antenna that came with the unit and leaving the insulation around the center conductor) that is terminated with a male BNC connector. I had put a small amount of silicone caulk around the base of the antenna/center conductor and BNC connector. The coax is not real rigid and sort of flops around, but I like that better than the rigid antenna. My range from transmitter to receiver is about 1400'. Hope this helps others that may have a water problem.

Reviews.Title: Excellant New, Deteriorates Rapidly
Reviews.Author: bobf "bobf"
Reviews.Content: Over the last couple of years I have bought quite a few Dakota Alert sensors (4 regular, 4 MURS, 2 buried sensors for cars).  These units all worked VERY, VERY well when purchased. Their original range is excellent and it seems even better with the MURS units.  I also bought a hand-held radio to receive alerts from this PIR transmitter and can receive alerts from 500 to 700 feet with at least one hillside in between (line of sight is about 30 to 40 feet into the hillside).  I have set these units as far away as 2500 feet without a clear line of sight (going through a fair number of deciduous trees and a few firs to reach the house), although they only transmit through one wall of the house.As mentioned in the title, their long term reliability has been a problem for me.  Each unit usually lasts 8 to 12 months without a problem then goes downhill very fast.  I live in the PNW where it is VERY wet during the winter (though temps stay moderate).  Earlier units constantly had moisture inside when they failed.  Newer units have a vent hole yet still have condensation and eventually rusting inside.  I have tried covering units with plastic bags and duct tape to no avail.  Also, the antenna (which telescopes) tends to fill with water when it rains as well.The most common failure mode is a constant repeated alert (drives you crazy till you disconnect it).  Often, I have brought the offending unit indoors for several days to dry out and was able to put it back into service for up to several weeks before it died again with the same problem.  I have returned at least 4 units within their one year warranty for this problem and the new units act the same - good for 8-12 months depending on the weather, then recurring problems until they die completely.I have also tried spraying the interior of one unit with Corrosion-X (reputed to work to waterproof electronics without damaging the circuitry by ham operators).  The unit has not worked since I sprayed it :).If you need reliable SHORT-TERM sensors, these are awesome.  If you can't afford the $80 to $200 a year to replace them, then you may want to reconsider.  I have not yet found any other sensor that works as well as these - when they work.  Indoor use, or a method to waterproof the sensors, may also alleviate these problems.bobf

Reviews.Title: Good idea, poor implementation
Reviews.Author: Eustis
Reviews.Content: Dakota has a good concept here, but has not provided the quality needed. Having used these for three years in Northern NH, I have had to send all four units back to the factory for repair or replacement, some more than once, in the warranty period. And they are very sensitive to weather.  Foggy and rainy weather cuts the effective distance down considerably and has caused water penetration around the antenna. Cold weather will sometimes kill a unit.  To Dakota's credit, they repair or replace with no questions asked if the unit is in the warranty period.  Personally, I would prefer a higher quality unit the works without any problems.

Reviews.Title: Works as advertised
Reviews.Author: Eagle Vision
Reviews.Content: I needed a second transmitter since my driveway is quite long.  I get false alarms from wildlife so a second node would confirm, to me, that someone is approaching up the driveway.Once I inserted the batteries, and set the proper channel, it was ready to go.  It was synchronized with the base.  The transmitter is identical to the one that ships with the base unit.  LED can be toggled, degree of sensitivity to objects, and channels can be changed.Aside from securing to a post or tree, there is nothing really to it.  The case is water resistant and snaps in place.  I noticed some light rust along the base of the antenna and a rubber coating may have made it more resistant to the elements.Overall, it's a solid addition to my Dakota system.  If your driveway is quite long (> 025 miles), it helps to have more than one transmitter.

Reviews.Title: Does not work in cold weather
Reviews.Author: Fred
Reviews.Content: I've just purchased and configured two transmitters and found that set up was fairly straightforward.  What is troubling me is that these transmitters just will not work if the outside temperature is below 50 degrees F.  I have reconfigured, set up, moved around these transmitters to over a dozen locations and found that although they work well indoors (warm), they absolutely refuse to work outside in anything under 50 degrees regardless of the time of day or weather conditions.  In my mind, this completely disqualifies these for anything useful outside.Update:  Updated to 3 star from 1 star rating.  After calling Dakota Alert, they asked me to return the transmitters.  They had to replace the sensor board in both and did so without charge.  They were returned to me promptly.. making me wonder if the reseller didn't send me broken devices?  Gotta wonder.

Reviews.Title: Great product but two modifications make it evenbetter
Reviews.Author: Aaronm
Reviews.Content: I have been using two of these on my property for over a year and they work great. Just bought two more to monitor a back driveway.The two complaints that I see a lot can be easily fixed.1)- the antenna connections and the pull out antenna will not keep out water. I recommend wrapping the antenna joints and the connector at the base in some kind of sealant. I used butyl putty tape from my RV windows but I'm sure there are other options.2)- the AA batteries do not last that long if you get frequent traffic. Mine lasts 6 monts with around 6-8 cars per day. According to other reviews online this product is designed to work on voltages up to around 12v so I just use a small 12V game camera battery and a small solar charger that you can get specifically for them. Drill a hole in the bottom of the housing, run wires through the hole and seal with butyl tape. Never have another dead battery.Note: you can also use a regular weather/police scanner to hear the alerts on multiple frequencies. Very handy.Very good product.

Reviews.Title: Be warned
Reviews.Author: Shopper
Reviews.Content: I ordered three Dakota Alert transmitters with receivers to install at my house entrances.  They worked beautifully for a few weeks and now two of them have gone silent and and the third one works intermittently.  We have checked batteries, settings, locations and all,  and cannot find the trouble.  I am very disgusted.  I bought these products on the strength of the Dakota Alert driveway alarm I have which has worked dependably for several years.My advice is Don't Buy this product.

Reviews.Title: This model works ok
Reviews.Author: R. Gadd "tool user"
Reviews.Content: The original models of these transmitters claimed 1/4 mile range which was a dream at best.  Although the current models don't reach their 3 mile range they do perform with strong and consistent performance up to 3/8 of a mile.  I would suggest these to a friend.

Reviews.Title: can's get it to work
Reviews.Author: Tom
Reviews.Content: it wouldn't work on first try. Sent back to mfg and they returned it with the wrong antenna.Trying to return it permanently!!

Reviews.Title: Ignore the bad reviews
Reviews.Author: Kurtglo "K. Michael"
Reviews.Content: I have had mine for 2 1/2 years now with NO problems. Make sure you use lithium batteries and not alkaline. I read some of the reviews from other buyers and I must say, they lack common sense. If you live where it gets cold outside, put some good batteries in it. Not only will you get .25 of a mile range but the batteries will last for over a year. At least mine did and it gets -20 below out in ur winter.I have 4 of these alert transmitters and each one works top-notch. Trust me! If you have a problem with any of the equipment, call their customer support and the friendly staff will help you make it right!KG

Reviews.Title: It does come with a flexable rubber antenna
Reviews.Author: Larry Fasnacht
Reviews.Content: Unlike the previous model, and the photo picturing the item, the new version comes with a "rubber-duck" antenna instead of the metal telescoping one pictured.

Reviews.Title: Still serving a captive market  and making tiny strides
Reviews.Author: sancocho
Reviews.Content: Firstly, this device works.  However, it will degrade gradually if left exposed to the elements.  The problems arise from its overall design and execution.  Earlier versions of the housing attempted to completely seal the internals but this resulted in certain condensation and degradation of the electronics.  Also at issue was the retractable, metal antenna which would allow water into the housing.  The current version is ventilated via small screens surrounding the antenna mount and also one acting as a drain/vent on the bottom of the housing.  They've also switched to a SMA male rubber duck antenna.  I can follow the logic behind these changes but users still report problems arriving from the relatively open-air environment of the internals.  It's a catch-22 that can only really be solved by much better protected circuits and making the housing an extra layer of protection, not primary.  Dakota seem content with the device largely unchanged so we need a competitor to enter the market or we fix it ourselves:  Buy a marine battery box and roll of silicon pipe sealing/electrical sealing tape, ~$15 for both.  Throw away the lid and mount the transmitter inside the battery box as another layer of protection.  Drill a hole for the antenna and wrap the section protruding with the sealing tape against the top of the battery box.This transmits on all MURS channels and CTCSS tones and transmits at 1.1 watts.  There are three sensitivity/range settings as well.  The voice on this latest iteration is now female, a little more sing-songy, and less matter-of-fact than the male voice on previous versions.

Reviews.Title: Excellent visitor early warning
Reviews.Author: Incitatus "Conspicuous Consumer"
Reviews.Content: Works like a charm.  I have it at the end of a 600 yard driveway and it reliably announces visitors.  Gotta say that getting an alarm at 3am is disconcerting.  We put it on a timer so it is off in the middle of the night (our concern is not intruders, we just want to know when people are driving up).

Reviews.Title: I bought this to supplement my existing system and it was easy to...
Reviews.Author: Dan the Man
Reviews.Content: program and now I have a total of 4 remotes at all of my points of entry to my property.  The remote unit has been redesigned to now utilize a rubber duck antenna and the outer case is now black in color as well.  The range of the remote is just as good as the original units that utilized a telescoping whip antenna.  Each remote has a programmable zone selector switch so the system will annunciate which remote is being activated.  Range of these units is approximately 1 mile but depending on your location greater distance is possible.  I highly recommend this product!

Reviews.Title: DAKOTA ALERT - GOODPRODUCT
Reviews.Author: gordon n cole
Reviews.Content: VERY PLEASE WITH THIS DRIVE WAY ALERT SYSTEMi HAVE TWO OF THEM IN USE ON MY PROPERTY.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

Reviews.Title: I can't believe I bought another Dakota Transmitter
Reviews.Author: augustus grainger
Reviews.Content: For 10 years I have used these Dakota alert transmitters, pagers,and  hand held receivers, It is a love/ hate relationship. Sometimes they work great. Sometimes they don't. Mostly they don't  I can't explain it any better than that. It seems like they could improve on them.  It seems like they could work better.  I have the long distance transmitter.  I have short distance transmitters.  At times (with new batteries) I can't get a signal from 10 feet away.  They are disgusting.  I get stressed out just looking at the sorry things.  I better quit typing before I give them 1 star.  I bought a Chamberlain and I believe they say it is good up to a half mile and I just laughed.  Ha Ha.  Probably lies.  I will find out though.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic System
Reviews.Author: diverven
Reviews.Content: I love the way this whole system works! Highly recommend Dakota Alert to everyone interested in security. Easy to use pretty much plug and play type. I purchased four transmitters, one for each of the four corners of my five acre property.  Simply install batteries, flip a switch to set your zones, and hang on a tree or post, and your done. The signal gets set back to the receiver.

Reviews.Title: Dakota Alert MURS Transmitter
Reviews.Author: Donald E. Fields
Reviews.Content: Ordered two. Had to send one back to Dakota Alert, Inc. for Repair/Replacement. When the unit transmitted is made a Static Sound and not very much volume. Did not meet my expectations. However I have other Dakota Alert units ordered from other dealers that seem to work fine.

Reviews.Title: No better than the Dakota Alert 3000
Reviews.Author: Joel Parker
Reviews.Content: Bought this thinking the external antennae might give it longer range. Alas this is not so. It worked less consistently than my Dakota Alert 3000.

Reviews.Title: works but needs work
Reviews.Author: Stephen Simon "mozart"
Reviews.Content: it works ok but I have it 500 ft away and it works some times.  I'm not sure if I trust it right now.

Reviews.Title: Good unit
Reviews.Author: D. Satterthwaite "Sath"
Reviews.Content: My drive is a mile long and goes up 600ft. in that mile and the Dokata Alert works as stated. This is my second one for an alert in another area on the drive. Good product!

Reviews.Title: MURS Review
Reviews.Author: Ronald E Wysong
Reviews.Content: Good product. I now have four of them. Works good and good customer service if needed.Works as advertised. Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: great alarm
Reviews.Author: finehorselife
Reviews.Content: The very best alarm for long distance. I found that the 3/4 mile to where we had to place the alarm wasn't any problem. I have used these Dakota Alarms for many years and they aren't any problem.

Reviews.Title: Dakota Alert MURS Alert Transmitter
Reviews.Author: ozark logman "oaklogman"
Reviews.Content: I have had  this unit in operation for about 4 weeks and it works great.  I order 4 of these units so that I would be able to monitor activity in 4 separate locations.. The service was great. Received the units in record time. I would do business with this seller again.

Reviews.Title: Works as advertised
Reviews.Author: Bluegrass Bassman
Reviews.Content: The system was easy to set up.  I installed two transmitters; each about 800 feet from the base station.  I'm having trouble with false readings and yesterday I was picking up voices so clear that I had to shut the system down. I need to change frequencies on the system once I figure out how to do so.This system replaced another driveway alarm system I had that was one fifth the cost of this one and worked for me for about 10 years before rusting out. I believe that this alarm system is way overpriced as I paid $244.00 with two birdhouses.

Reviews.Title: Very Satisfied
Reviews.Author: Tom/MO
Reviews.Content: This is the second unit we've purchased, to add to the original for coverage in a different direction.  In the past we have tried other systems, both expensive and cheap.  Our first unit is about 9 months old, and performing perfectly.  The new unit is facing directly west, and we were concerned that we would get false alerts caused by the afternoon sun as with previous systems.  No problem.  I painted it to match the building it's mounted on and although it's a large unit it blends in great.  After several years of trial and error we finally found a system that does everything we wanted.

Reviews.Title: Driveway Alarm
Reviews.Author: poco
Reviews.Content: I already had one receiver and one transmitter. This was just an add on transmitter to my driveway alarm system. My driveway is very long (over a half mile)and this alarm has a long range of transmission. It works very well for me. Windy days can be a problem, you don't want to set it up in an area where there is something swaying such as tall weeds or other tree limbs, across the road. May take some trial and error finding the right spot but when you do it works just as described. I would recommend this to anyone who has a long driveway.

Reviews.Title: No Range
Reviews.Author: Jim Clark
Reviews.Content: This is advertised as having a range of 80 feet and when I installed this the maximum range was 10 feet. It is a defective unit and will be returned for replacement. The second one works as advertised.
